channel.title: Latest PHMSA Hazardous Materials Incident Reports, for AL
channel.description: The latest Form 5800.1 hazardous material reports submitted to the Department of Transportation and posted online by the Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration, for AL

item.title: Report X-2024020460
item.description:
Report X-2024020460

Identified by scraper @ 2024-02-16T00:33:09+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-01-22
  • City: MADISON
  • State: AL
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: Fedex Ground Package System, Inc.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: SequenceEvent: PACKAGE WAS TAKEN FROM TRAILER WITH THE TOP DAMP. BOX WAS PLACED IN PLASTIC BAG THEN IN PLASTIC TUB. TOP WAS DAMP BUT NOT DRIPPING. DescribePack: THE SEAL UNDER THE LIDS WERE UNSEALED. THE LIDS HAVE SMALL HOLE IN THEM. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: BOX WAS PLACED IN PLASTIC BAG AND IN BIN

item.title: Report X-2024020209
item.description:
Report X-2024020209

Identified by scraper @ 2024-02-15T12:17:17+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-01-08
  • City: THEODORE
  • State: AL
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: Fedex Ground Package System, Inc.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: SequenceEvent: The glue holding on the bottom of the package failed and all 4 containers fell out and broke. Absorbent was used to clean up the spill and placed in a hazmat container. DescribePack: The bottom closure failed. The bottom was held with glue DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: The immediate area was cleared, and absorbent was used to clean the spill.

  • Description: SequenceEvent: Package was brought back by driver. QA placed package in a leakproof hazmat tote for further inspection. DescribePack: Bottom edge of the 5-gallon bucket was cracked. Approx 4in length DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: Package was placed in leakproof lined hazmat tote immediately after receiving.

item.title: Report E-2024020008
item.description:
Report E-2024020008

Identified by scraper @ 2024-02-15T12:17:17+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-01-30
  • City: BIRMINGHAM
  • State: AL
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: CSX TRANSPORTATION, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On January 30th, 2024, at 1346 hours, personnel at the CSX Boyles Terminal in Birmingham, Alabama, reported a suspect odor from an inbound train. Marion Environmental, Inc. (MEI), a CSX emergency response contractor, and Davy Ferguson, a CSX Manager of Hazardous Materials, responded to investigate. Upon investigation the area, response personnel discovered GATX 60194, a loaded tank car of Sulfur, Molten, was leaking vapor from the manway cover due to (1) of (6) manway cover bolts being less than tool tight. The car was isolated and the shipper, Contango Resources, was notified via CHEMTREC (Report 2024-01-30-00168). Response personnel properly secured the manway cover and stopped the release. The defect found and correction actions were communicated to the shipperâ€™s representative- Ross Goff (307-840-1078).

item.title: Report E-2024020092
item.description:
Report E-2024020092

Identified by scraper @ 2024-02-12T18:12:40+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-01-31
  • City: BIRMINGHAM
  • State: AL
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R&L CARRIERS SHARED SERVICES, L.L.C.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On January 31, 2024, one (1) 5-gallon pail of UN3266 was forked and released approximately five (5) gallons of product to the dock floor. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Miller Environmental Group (MEG) to remediate the impacted site. MEG removed the damaged container from the pallet and deployed absorbents to the released material. All spent absorbents were collected and containerized into one (1) 55-gallon poly drum and staged onsite.
